chunks.chunk_text: August 2020 saw the hottest temperature recorded anywhere in modern times – 54.4 degrees Celsius in California's Death Valley.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Melting ice sheet_ Is it too late_.json

chunks.chunk_text: But global heating and melting polar ice has many scientists asking whether it's now too late to stop. Have we reached the point of no return? In this programme, we'll be looking at the effects of climate change on the Arctic and asking if it's too late to change.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Melting ice sheet_ Is it too late_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Now, Georgina, you mentioned record levels of ice melt in the North Pole – that the scale is hard to take in. The amounts are so big they're measured in gigatons – that's a billion metric tons! Imagine a giant ice cube one kilometre by one kilometre by one kilometre! So, my quiz question is this – how many gigatons of ice are now melting into the ocean every year? Is it a. 450 gigatons?
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Melting ice sheet_ Is it too late_.json

chunks.chunk_text: B. 500 gigatons? Or C. 550 gigatons? I'll take a guess at B. 500 gigatons. OK, Georgina, we'll find out later. Now, glaciologist Michaela King has been monitoring the melting of Arctic ice by satellite. Here she is answering a question from BBC World Service programme Science in Action on whether the destruction of the ice sheet is now unavoidable.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Melting ice sheet_ Is it too late_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Ice is made from snow falling on Greenland's glaciers – large, slow-moving masses of ice.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Melting ice sheet_ Is it too late_.json

chunks.chunk_text: At the same time, though, ice is also lost through melting. But now the glaciers are shrinking faster, the new ice is being accumulated and the situation may have reached a tipping point – the time at which a change or an effect cannot be stopped.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Melting ice sheet_ Is it too late_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Does this mean that global heating and ice melting are now running automatically, separate from the amount of greenhouse gases humans are pumping into the atmosphere? And does that mean we should just give up on the planet? In fact, the situation is far from simple, as Michaela King explains here to BBC World Service programme Science in Action.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Melting ice sheet_ Is it too late_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Michaela thinks that changes in human activity can still slow the rate, or speed, at which something happens – in this case, the speed of Greenland's ice sheet melting.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Melting ice sheet_ Is it too late_.json

chunks.chunk_text: It's a positive message, but one which calls for everyone to do what they can before it really is too late. Because the rate of ice melt is still increasing, right, Neil? Yes, that's right. In fact, that was my quiz question, Georgina. Do you remember? Yes. You asked me how many gigatons of Greenland's ice sheet
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Melting ice sheet_ Is it too late_.json

chunks.chunk_text: are now melting every year. I said B – 500 gigatons. And you were… Correct! In fact, some of these giant ice cubes are like small towns, almost a kilometre tall. So there's still work to be done. In this programme, we've been looking at the rate, or speed, of ice melt in Greenland's ice sheet – the thick layer of ice covering a large area of the Arctic. Previously, the melting ice was replaced by newly formed ice on glaciers – large
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Melting ice sheet_ Is it too late_.json

chunks.chunk_text: masses of slow-moving ice. This kept the Arctic in balance, having different elements arranged in proportion. But the effects of global heating have brought us close to a point of no return, called a tipping point – the time at which a change or an effect cannot be stopped. The situation is serious, but there's still time to take action and not simply throw your hands up. Show frustration and despair when you want to give up.
